document.docAuthor: Nakayama, Ryo, Sasaki, Takenori & Nakano, Tomoyuki
document.docTitle: Lottia goshimai Nakayama & Sasaki & Nakano 2017, n. sp.
document.masterDocTitle: Molecular analysis reveals a new cryptic species in a limpet Lottia kogamogai (Patellogastropoda: Lottiidae) from Japan

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Molecular analysis reveals a new cryptic species in a limpet Lottia kogamogai (Patellogastropoda: Lottiidae) from Japan

subSubSection.paragraph:
Collisella heroldi :
Niu et al . 1992
, figs 2A–C.

Lottia kogamogai : Sasaki & Okutani, 1994b
, pl. 2a–c.
Lottia kogamogai
:
Fukui & Kashio, 2012
, p. 22, pls 3–2.
Lottia cf. kogamogai :
Kristof et al . 2016
, p. 2, fig. 1a.

Type materials.
Holotype (
UMUT-RM 32483
), Usujiri , Hakodate , Hokkaido , Japan , 10.8 x 8.2 x 3.8 mm . Selected paratypes : Paratype 1 (NSMT-Mo78956)
; Paratype 2 (NSMT-Mo78957); Paratype 3 (UMUT-RM32492); Paratype 4 (UMUT-RM32471), Paratype 5 (UMUT-RM32496); Paratype 6 (UMUT-RM32494); Paratype 7 (UMUT- RM32479). Remaining paratypes are also deposited at UMUT (UMUT RM3232467-32505).

Shell ( Figures 2 , 3 ).
Shell moderately thick, aperture oval. Apex antero-dorsally directed and positioned at anterior fourth. Anterior and ventral slopes nearly straight, posterior slope convex. Exterior surface sculptured by crowded, rough, regularly arranged radial riblets. Exterior colour light brown with 12 brown radial rays. Interior margin alternating light brown and dark brown; intermediate area white; central area except apex stained dark chocolate brown; apex area white.
Animal. Dorsal part of mantle margin fringed with light brown. Head and visceral mass dark beige. Ventral surface creamy white.

Lottia
species.
A – H.
Lottia goshimai
n. sp. A.

, UMUT- RM32494, Shirakami, Matsumae, Hokkaido (Loc. D); 8.9 x 7.0 x 5.6 mm. H. Paratype 7, on

, UMUT- RM32479, Esan, Hakodate, Hokkaido (Loc. G); 9.6 x 7.8 x 5.0 mm. I.

, on rocks, UMUT-RM32514, Onna, Okinawa (Loc. r); 10.5 x 8.3 x 4.7 mm. J.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Radula ( Figure 4 ).
First lateral teeth relatively short with pointed cusp. Second lateral teeth long with slightly rounded cusp. Third lateral teeth broad with beak-like cusps. Marginal teeth small, rounded.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Type locality.
Usujiri , Hakodate , Hokkaido , Japan ( 41°56'11"N , 140°57'00"E ).

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Northern part of Japan from Erimo, Hokkaido to Karakuwa, Miyagi on the Pacific coast and Monbetsu, Hokkaido to Tsuruoka, Yamagata , Vostok Bay, Russia in the Japan Sea.

Habitat. This species lives in the middle to lower intertidal zone, and is often seen among the small barnacle
Chthamalus challengeri
and on the purplish mussel
Septifer virgatus
.

Remarks. Although the new species is morphologically similar to
L. kogamogai
, it is distinguished by having rough, fine and regularly-arranged radial riblets ( Fig. 3 ). The radulae differ in terms of the morphology of the lateral teeth.
Lottia goshimai
n. sp.
has short first lateral teeth, a long and slightly rounded cusp on the second lateral teeth, and slightly beak-like third lateral teeth ( Figs. 4 A–D).
Lottia kogamogai
has long and rounded first lateral teeth, a broad and pointed cusp on the second lateral teeth, and short, broad third lateral teeth ( Figs. 4 E–H). Intraspecific variation was observed within
L. goshimai
n. sp.
and
L. kogamogai
in shell and radular morphogy. The individuals living on the shell of
Septifer virgatus
have taller, darker shells and shorter second lateral teeth than those from rocks ( Figs. 2 , 4 ).

The
Lottia kogamogai
complex is clearly divided according to geographical distribution of each species:
Lottia goshimai
n. sp.
,
L. kogamogai
and
L. luchuana
are limited to northern Japan , southern Japan and tropical Japan respectively ( Fig. 5 ). Although
L. tenuisculpta
and
L. lindbergi
have a wide distribution along temperate Japan ( Sasaki & Okutani 1994b ), these two species were not analyzed intensively in this paper.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5. The geographical distribution of three
Lottia
species with warm sea currents around Japan. The record of
Lottia goshimai
n.sp.
from Russian coast is from Kristof et al. (2016).

FIGURE 6. Phylogenetic tree of Bayesian analysis based on COI data (661 bp). The numbers above each branch are NJ bootstrap/MP bootstrap/Bayesian posterior probabilities. Three species of
Nipponacmea
were used as outgroup.
